data.title: Here's where 54 celebrities went to college
data.meta_description: Jessica Chastain, John Legend, and Emma Watson are all accomplished college graduates, among a number of celebrities with college degrees.
data.text:
This story is available exclusively to Business Insider subscribers. Become an Insider and start reading now. Have an account? .

Mindy Kaling, Viola Davis, and Lupita Nyong'o studied theater in college.

Some celebrities, like Emma Watson and Steven Spielberg, went to college after they became famous.

Kourtney Kardashian is the only Kardashian sibling with a college degree.

Advertisement

Emma Watson, just like Hermione, is really smart. She went to Brown.

The "Harry Potter" actress graduated in 2014 with a degree in English literature. She also took classes at Oxford University.

Lupita Nyong'o landed her Oscar-winning role shortly before graduating with a Yale master's degree.

She landed her role in "12 Years a Slave" before completing her three-year degree in acting at the Ivy League school in 2012. For her undergraduate degree, she attended Hampshire College.

Advertisement

Conan O'Brien was the president of Harvard University's satirical paper.

The Harvard Lampoon is a resume marker for many male comedians and writers, including B.J. Novak and John Updike. Conan O'Brien had a stint as the organization's president and graduated in 1985.

While O'Brien was at Harvard, the editor in chief of the Harvard Crimson, the rival, non-humorous student newspaper, was Jeff Zucker. Later, as an executive at NBC, Zucker took "The Tonight Show" away from O'Brien and gave it to Jay Leno.

Advertisement

James Franco went to a lot of colleges.

He dropped out of UCLA at first, but then finished his degree in 2008 as an undergraduate.

As a master's student, he's attended New York University, Columbia University, Brooklyn College, and Yale University.

Advertisement

John Legend turned down a scholarship from Harvard to go to the University of Pennsylvania.

He graduated in 1999 and served as president of a co-ed a capella group while he was there.

Mindy Kaling wrote plays and a comic strip at Dartmouth University.

Graduating in 2001, the comedian majored in theater and illustrated a daily comic for the student newspaper called "Badly Drawn Girl."

Advertisement

Natalie Portman went to Harvard University after starring in "Star Wars."

Portman was still a student at Syosset High School in Long Island, New York, when she filmed "Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace." Afterwards, she attended Harvard University, graduating in 2003 with a degree in psychology. Her academic work has been published twice in scientific journals.

Matt Damon came up with the idea for "Good Will Hunting" while at Harvard University.

It explains a lot about the plot of "Good Will Hunting," which follows a gifted janitor at MIT, another Cambridge school. He ended up dropping out before graduating in 1992 to pursue acting, but he received an honorary degree from the school in 2013.

Advertisement

Mayim Bialik has a doctorate in neuroscience.

The "Blossom" and "Big Bang Theory" actress — and now "Jeopardy!" host — switched between acting and academia. In 2000, she received an undergraduate degree in neuroscience with minors in Hebrew and Jewish studies from the University of California, Los Angeles. She was awarded a PhD in neuroscience from the school in 2007.

Maggie and Jake Gyllenhaal both attended Columbia, but only Maggie graduated.

The elder Gyllenhaal, Maggie, graduated in 1998. Her brother joined the school when she was a senior, but dropped out his sophomore year to pursue acting.

Advertisement

Jessica Chastain is Julliard-trained.

Chastain graduated from the famous performin-arts school in 2003. She was able to attend because of a scholarship funded by Robin Williams, who himself graduated in 1976 funded by a full scholarship, The Guardian reported.

Ken Jeong was pre-med at Duke University before getting a medical degree.

The "Hangover" and "Dr. Ken" star is a licensed obstetrician. He graduated from Duke University in 1990 and obtained his medical degree in 1995 at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill School of Medicine.

Advertisement

Denzel Washington played college basketball at Fordham University.

He decided to go with acting instead, and received degrees in drama and journalism in 1977.

Jodie Foster went to Yale, but acted through the summers.

Graduating from Yale University in 1985, Jodie Foster became a role model for many child actors who wanted to get an education while maintaining a career in Hollywood.

Advertisement

Ellie Kemper went to two of the best schools in the world.

The "Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt" star graduated from Princeton University in 2002 with a degree in English and then spent a year getting a graduate degree in the same subject at Oxford University. After graduating, she spent a year interning for "Late Night with Conan O'Brien" in New York.

Steven Spielberg graduated from California State University — 34 years late.

The legendary director dropped out in 1968. But decades later, he returned to finish up his remaining credits and get his degree. He submitted "Schindler's List," which won seven Oscars, as one of his student films for a course. It passed.

Advertisement

Michael Jordan didn't give up college when he went pro.

As an NCAA player, Jordan was a student at the University of North Carolina. After he got drafted in 1984, he still took classes and graduated in 1986.

Kourtney Kardashian, a University of Arizona grad, is the only Kardashian sibling with a college degree.

She graduated with a degree in theater in 2002. Her mother, Kris Jenner, doesn't have a college degree, but her father is famed lawyer Robert Kardashian, who attended USC and University of San Diego School of Law. Her sister Kim, who is a successful businesswoman, has aspirations to follow in their father's footsteps and become a lawyer.

Advertisement

Brad Pitt majored in journalism at the University of Missouri.

He dropped out to pursue acting two weeks before graduating, Poynter reported.

Tom Hanks went to Chabot College in California.

Hanks had low expectations when it came to getting accepted to colleges. He ended up attending Chabot College, a local community college that was affordable for him and his family, for two years before transferring to California State University, Sacramento in 1972. He wrote about his experience at Chabot in a 2015 essay for The New York Times, titled, "I Owe It All to Community College."

Advertisement

Octavia Spencer went to school in Alabama.

Octavia Spencer graduated from Auburn University in 1994, and started acting professionally two years after college.

Oprah Winfrey got a full scholarship to Tennessee State University.

She attended the historically-Black university after winning an oratory contest that got her a full scholarship and winning the Miss Black Tennessee pageant.

Advertisement

Sandra Bullock did theater productions while at East Carolina University.

Before graduating in 1987, she acted in productions of "Peter Pan" and "Three Sisters."

Advertisement

Meryl Streep went to Vassar College and Yale.

Streep started considering acting as a potential career after starring in a production of "Miss Julie" at Vassar in 1969. After graduating in 1971, she took a couple of years off before enrolling in the Yale School of Drama, earning her master's degree in 1975.

Adam Sandler went to New York University's Tisch School of the Arts.

He got his degree in 1988, performing comedy routines in clubs while he was still a student, and started writing for "Saturday Night Live" in 1990.

Advertisement

Viola Davis studied acting at Rhode Island College before going to Julliard.

Growing up in poverty, Davis told The New Yorker in 2016 that she struggled to get a good education. She was able to attend Rhode Island College on a full scholarship, graduating in 1988 with a degree in theater. After graduating, she was one of the few actors accepted into Julliard, where she received a degree in 1993.

John Cho briefly taught English after graduating from UC Berkeley.

Born in South Korea, Cho moved to the US as a kid and grew up in Los Angeles. He graduated from the University of California, Berkeley with an English degree in 1996 and taught English while pursuing his acting career, according to the Center for Asian American Media.

Advertisement

Mahershala Ali went to Saint Mary's College of California on a basketball scholarship.

In an interview on the university's official website, he said he didn't enjoy basketball by the time he graduated in 1996.

"Honestly, I kind of resented basketball by the end of my time there," he said. "I'd seen guys on the team get chewed up, spat out and I was personally threatened with being shipped off to the University of Denver. All in the name of wins and productivity."

He studied mass communication while there and began to participate in poetry slams.

Advertisement

Kathryn Hahn studied theater at Northwestern and then Yale.

She graduated from Northwestern in 1995 and the Yale School of Drama in 2001. She said she struggled to play serious roles.

In a 2013 interview with the Observer, she said, "In 'Hamlet,' I played Polonius, which was already hilarious. It was very hard for me to not wink, especially during the death scene. It was hard for me to not tip it over to the other side."

Advertisement

Chris Pine wasn't entirely interested in acting while studying at the University of California, Berkeley.

Though his parents acted, Pine chose to be an English major before wandering into acting. After graduating in 2002, he attended the Williamstown Theatre Festival in Massachusetts and continued taking acting classes while pursuing his career.

"I never had a passion for acting, I never wanted to do it," he told The Hollywood Reporter in 2016. "But like any human being — people want to be loved, and it seemed to be the thing I could do where I got love."

Issa Rae graduated from Stanford University after majoring in African and African-American studies and minoring in political science.

Before graduating in 2007, Rae created a mockumentary called "Dorm Diaries." After graduating, she became well-known for her web series "The Mis-adventures of Awkward Black Girl" and broke out in Hollywood as the creator, cowriter, and star of HBO's "Insecure."

Advertisement

Riz Ahmed went to Oxford University to study philosophy, politics, and economics.

While at college, Ahmed thought about leaving, but then he decided to fill his time with something he liked and created a club night called "Hit and Run" and a drama group, The Guardian reported. He graduated in 2003.

Julianne Moore studied theater as an undergrad.

Moore graduated from the College of Fine Arts in 1983 and then moved to New York City and worked as a waitress before her acting career took off, she told The Guardian.

Advertisement

The "Walking Dead" star Steven Yeun majored in psychology at Kalamazoo.

Yeun graduated from Kalamazoo College in 2005. He discovered his love of acting after watching a performance of college improv group Monkapult, MLive reported. He ended up taking an improv class and joining the group. After graduating, he moved to Chicago to pursue his career.

Tina Fey threw herself into the drama department as a student at the University of Virginia.

Fey studied playwriting and acting as a student, Parade reported. After graduating in 1992, she moved to Chicago to pursue her comedy career at Second City.

Advertisement

Pedro Pascal moved to New York from Orange County to attend New York University.

Pascal got into drama in middle school. He ended up auditioning for and getting into the Orange Country School of the Arts before heading off to NYU.

"I begged my parents to let me go, and I won that fight so I ended up in New York in '93 and sort of got stuck here," he said in an interview with So It Goes.

Amy Poehler was part of improv group My Mother's Fleabag at Boston College.

Poehler graduated with a degree in media and communications in 1993. She then moved to Chicago and studied improv at Second City, which is where she met Tina Fey.

Advertisement

Kumail Nanjiani double majored in philosophy and computer science at Grinnell College, a small liberal arts school in Iowa.

While there, he stumbled into stand-up comedy and tried it for the first time as a senior, he told The Washington Post. After graduating, he moved to Chicago to try his hand at it, and the risk was worth it.

Anne Hathaway had already started her career when she decided to take classes at Vassar.

She spent her freshman year as an English major, but then took a break to continue pursuing her career, The New York Times reported. She eventually transferred to New York University's Gallatin School of Individualized Study, but she ended up not graduating.

Advertisement

Daniel Dae Kim studied political science at Haverford College.

The Haverford grad took an acting class as an elective in college and decided he wanted to pursue it after graduating in 1990.

"Once I took acting, something opened up for me," he said in a 2015 interview with NBC. "Something changed in me. So I took as many acting courses as I could, and I pursued an independent major in acting at a local neighboring college because my college didn't have an acting major. After that, when all of my friends were joining places like Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley, I bucked the trend and ended up going to New York to act."

He ended up going to NYU for a master's degree and graduated in 1996.

Elizabeth Banks graduated magna cum laude from the University of Pennsylvania.

The actress studied communications and theater arts at the University of Pennsylvania before graduating in 1996, according to the university's official website. She was also a member of Delta Delta Delta. She went on to earn her master's at the American Conservatory Theater in 1998.

Advertisement

Oscar Isaac attended community college before becoming a Julliard grad.

The actor took classes at Miami Dade College and studied theater there before auditioning for Julliard on a whim while acting in an Off-Broadway show in New York. He graduated in 2005, Rolling Stone reported.

Rashida Jones went to Harvard.

Jones earned her BA in comparative religion from Harvard in 1997, according to the university's official website. She showed her musical and theatrical talents by writing music scores, performing in campus plays, and acting as the musical director of the co-ed a cappella group.

Advertisement

John Krasinski was involved with the sketch comedy group Out of Bounds while at Brown.

Krasinski spent his first semester teaching English in Costa Rica before returning to Brown as an English major with a focus on playwriting, The Brown Daily Herald reported. His time in the theater school made him want to pursue acting. He interned at "Late Night with Conan O'Brien" and graduated in 2001. He later studied at the O'Neill National Theater Institute.

Uzo Aduba was a top sprinter at Boston University.

In college, Aduba was both an athlete and a talented opera singer and actress. She graduated from the school of music with a focus on voice performance in 2005 and served as its commencement speaker in 2017.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Frances McDormand became BFFs with Holly Hunter in grad school.

The "Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri" actress graduated from Bethany College in 1979 with a degree in theater, The New York Times reported.

Afterwards, she went to Yale for a master's degree in drama, which she received in 1982. While she was there, she roomed with actress Holly Hunter. The two got along so well that they continued to live together when they moved to New York City after graduation.

Stephen Colbert graduated from Northwestern University.

Colbert transferred to Northwestern as a junior and completed the school's three-year acting program in two years. He gave the commencement speech and received an honorary doctorate at his alma mater in 2011.

Advertisement

Kerry Washington double majored in anthropology and sociology at George Washington University.

Washington, who was a presidential scholar for the arts at GW, delivered the commencement speech and received an honorary doctorate in 2013.

Colin Jost graduated from Harvard in 2004.

During his time at Harvard, Jost majored in history and literature and wrote for the Harvard Lampoon. He lived in the same dorm as transportation secretary Pete Buttigieg, CNN reported.

Advertisement

Gabrielle Union graduated from UCLA with a degree in sociology.

Union played soccer for the University of Nebraska before transferring to Cuesta College and finishing her college education at UCLA, according to IMDb. She earned her sociology degree from UCLA in 1996.

Advertisement

Stockard Channing majored in history and literature at Radcliffe College in 1965 before it merged with Harvard University.

Channing discovered her love of acting in college when she played Jenny in a production of "The Threepenny Opera."

"I found I could do things I didn't know I could do," she told Backstage in 2012. "It all came together."

Radcliffe, formerly a women's college, merged with Harvard in 1999.

Read next

Advertisement
